verses.text: Protect me, O God, for in You I take refuge.
verses.comment: David begins this Psalm as a prayer of trust, seeking God's protection. This theme echoes throughout the Psalms and reveals David's dependence, pointing to the trust believers place in God for security.

verses.text: I said to the LORD, 'You are my Lord; I have no good apart from You.'
verses.comment: This verse shows a confession of God’s ultimate goodness. Jesus also expressed that only God is good (Mark 10:18), affirming the unity and source of all true goodness in God.

verses.text: As for the saints who are in the land, they are the noble ones in whom is all my delight.
verses.comment: Here, 'saints' refers to the faithful people of God. The unity among the faithful is highlighted, foreshadowing the close communion and shared joy of all believers in the family of God.

verses.text: Those who run after other gods multiply their sorrows; I will not pour out their drink offerings of blood, nor take their names on my lips.
verses.comment: Rejecting idolatry, the Psalm distinguishes between the joy of serving the one true God and the emptiness of false gods. This contrast is seen throughout Scripture and shapes a distinctly exclusive worship.

verses.text: The LORD is my portion and my cup; You hold my lot.
verses.comment: To say God is our 'portion and cup' expresses full satisfaction found only in Him. The imagery also connects with the idea of a chosen inheritance and the very real gift of God’s presence, which finds fuller fulfillment in the life of Christ.

verses.text: The boundary lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; yes, I have a delightful inheritance.
verses.comment: This inheritance refers ultimately to the spiritual promises fulfilled in Christ, who brings believers into a greater inheritance, not just in land but in everlasting life and communion with God.

verses.text: I will bless the LORD who gives me counsel; even at night my heart instructs me.
verses.comment: David praises God’s guidance—both externally (through His word) and internally (in the heart). This guidance is extended to believers through the ongoing teaching of God’s Spirit.

verses.text: I have set the LORD always before me; because He is at my right hand, I will not be shaken.
verses.comment: This confidence foreshadows the unwavering trust Jesus exhibited, even facing suffering. Peter quotes this Psalm in reference to Christ’s resurrection (Acts 2:25), indicating a messianic meaning.

verses.text: Therefore my heart is glad, and my whole being rejoices; my flesh also dwells secure.
verses.comment: Both body and soul are secure in God’s promise. The New Testament links this joy and security to Jesus’ resurrection, promising hope beyond the grave to all who are united to Him.

verses.text: For You will not abandon my soul to Sheol, nor will You let Your Holy One see decay.
verses.comment: A prophecy applied directly to Jesus by the apostles (Acts 2:27). Jesus’ resurrection fulfills this promise of not seeing decay, confirming His holiness and the Father’s faithfulness.

verses.text: You make known to me the path of life; in Your presence there is fullness of joy; at Your right hand are pleasures forevermore.
verses.comment: The path of life, fullness of joy, and everlasting pleasures are the promises given to those who dwell in God’s presence. This finds its deepest meaning in eternal life with Christ, sustained by a living relationship through the sacraments and prayer.
